Graphical abstract The objective of this study is to explore the effect of catalyst synthesis procedure on the activity of catalysts for partial oxidation of methane. In this aspect, Pt-nanoparticles supported CeO2 catalysts were prepared by Hydrothermal, co-precipitation, impregnation and by controlled deposition of platinum nanoparticles on hydrothermally prepared cerium oxide. Prepared catalysts were characterized by BET-surface area, X-ray diffraction, H2-Chemisorption, Transmission electron microscopy, Temperature programmed reduction, Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. The study revealed that the catalyst preparation procedure plays a very crucial role on morphology, catalyst particle size, metal support interaction and activity of the catalysts. Catalytic activities were tested for partial oxidation of methane in the temperature range 350–800°C. The study revealed that the catalyst prepared by controlled deposition of Pt-nanoparticles on hydrothermally prepared cerium oxide showed better activity for partial oxidation of methane compared to the catalysts prepared by other conventional methods. Controlled deposition of Pt-nanoparticles generated better metal-support interaction compared to the catalysts prepared by conventional hydrothermal, co-precipitation and impregnation methods. All the catalysts showed excellent coke resisting ability but the deactivation of most of the catalyst was found to be caused by catalyst particles sintering and re-oxidation of the Pt particles during catalysis. Keywords Pt-nanoparticles CeO2 Metal-support interaction Partial oxidation Methane 1 Introduction Conversion of methane to valuable chemicals like methanol, formaldehyde, ethane, ethylene and synthesis gas attracted researchers because of the high abundance of methane [1–5]. Direct production of methanol, formaldehyde and coupled products are highly desirable but low conversion and low selectivity to these products limited the application [4,6–8]. Methane is also considered to be one of the major energy sources present on earth and industrially used mainly for synthesis gas (a variable mixture of carbon monoxide and hydrogen gas) production, by reforming reactions [9–15] Methane is the basic raw material for these synthesis gas production processes and highly available in the remote areas, from where its transportation is very much difficult due to gaseous state in normal atmospheric conditions [16–19]. Industrially synthesis gas is produced by steam reforming of methane, which is a highly endothermic reaction and very high temperature is required (>850°C) [15,20]. On the other hand, partial oxidation of methane (POM) is a slightly exothermic reaction, which minimizes energy requirement for the process [14,15,21]. POM is considered to be one of the most promising processes for synthesis gas production with very high efficiency [16,22–24]. As partial oxidation of methane has some advantages over steam reforming, like it is thermodynamically more favorable, produces syngas with H2/CO ratio 2 and it is slightly exothermic, which makes the process more energy saving [12,15]. The process has some disadvantages too. The main problem is catalyst deactivation and hot spot generation during catalysis, which raises some safety concerns. The reason for catalyst deactivation during catalysis for POM was reported to be coking, which blocks the active sites for the reaction to take place and it causes reactor plugging also. Decades of research revealed that noble metals (Pt, Rh, Ru etc.) [24–28] and 1st row transition metals (Ni, Fe, Co etc.) [12,14,15,19,29–33] are active for POM. Noble metals are highly active and far more stable during catalysis due to its coke resisting properties [24–26]. High costs of the noble metals are the main drawback for their application in the process. In terms of activity, only nickel (Ni) is comparable to noble metals for POM but nickel is highly coke sensitive [12,34,35]. Therefore, it is a very important and tough task for the researchers to develop a suitable catalyst with very high activity and stability for POM. For catalysts activity and stability catalyst supports are reported to play a major role [28,36–41]. Supports which are capable of suppressing coke deposition, highly thermally stable and much more active in lower temperature are favored for the process. Supports like CeO2 and CeO2-ZrO2 are favored because of its redox property and high OSC (oxygen storage capacity) [42–45]. These materials are prone to get reduced at reducing environment and oxidized at oxidizing environment [24,46,47]. High OSC of these materials are helpful for catalysts activity, as the property enhances coke removal mechanism at the catalysts surface during catalysis [24,42,47]. Metal supports like Al2O3, SiO2, MgO, La2O3, CeO2, ZrO2, CeO2-ZrO2 and different mixed oxides are extensively studied by the researchers for POM [12,14,15,25,27,39,48–50]. Lanza et al. reported Rh/ZrO2 and Rh/CeO2-ZrO2 catalysts for POM, where they showed that addition of CeO2 lowered the ignition temperature by 60°C [38]. Hori et al. reported Pt/CeZrO2/Al2O3 catalysts and claimed that the catalyst showed 24h of time on stream stability at 800°C, whereas significant decrease was observed in case of Pt/Al2O3 catalyst [51]. They reported that higher oxygen mobility in Pt/CeZrO2/Al2O3 catalyst played the part for catalysts time on stream stability. Bueno et al. [28] reported that Cerium oxide modifies structural and electronic properties of a catalyst, which increases reducibility of noble metals and increases catalyst activity. Recently, Kondratenko et al. reported the dependence of catalytic activity on Rh particles size supported over γ-Al2O3 and explained that smaller Rh particles were much more active than the larger ones for synthesis gas production by POM [52]. Our very recent report described the synthesis and activity of Pt-CeO2 catalyst for POM with 100h of time on stream stability at 800°C [21]. Catalyst preparation methods reported to have great influence on catalytic activity of the catalysts [14,17,53]. Here, we are reporting a comparative study of Pt-CeO2 catalysts prepared by different methods, which showed variable activities for POM depending on their physicochemical properties controlled by preparation methods. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis 2.1.1 Controlled deposition of Pt on CeO2 HT (2Pt-CeO2 CD) The catalyst was prepared by a two-step method. First, Cerium oxide nanocrystals were prepared by solvo-thermal method and then Pt nanoparticles were deposited over prepared CeO2 by controlled deposition approach. In a typical synthesis process, 5.02g of Poly-diallyldimethylammonium chloride (PDADMAC) was dissolved in 100ml ethanol by stirring it for 1h at room temperature (35°C). 6.53g of Cerium nitrate hexahydrate [Ce(NO3)2.6H2O] dissolved in 20ml distilled water was added slowly to the polymer solution and continued stirring for 1h. After 1h of stirring, pH of the solution was maintained to 12 by 5 (M) NaOH solution (in water). The whole mixture was stirred for 5h, until a thick gel was formed. The mixture gel was then put into a stainless steel autoclave and kept at 180°C for 48h. The autoclave was then cooled at room temperature and the precipitate was washed with excess water to remove sodium. Obtained precipitate was then dried at 100°C for 12h and calcined at 600°C for 6h in air. The prepared cerium oxide was denoted as CeO2 HT. In second step of the method, Pt nanoparticles were deposited over the prepared CeO2 HT nanocrystals by a controlled deposition approach in presence of cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB). First, 0.04g of tetraamineplatinum(II) nitrate [Pt(NH3)4(NO3)2] was dissolved in a solution containing 0.04g of CTAB dissolved in 10ml of ethanol and 10ml distilled water mixture. The Pt salt solution was then added drop wise to 1g of CeO2 HT dispersed in 100ml ethanol. The whole mixture was kept on stirring for 1h and 0.5ml of NH2NH2.H2O (reducing agent) was added slowly to the mixture solution and continued stirring for 2 more h at room temperature (30–35°C). Here both CTAB and hydrazine can act as capping agent also [54,55]. The temperature of the solution was raised to 60°C after 2h of stirring and the whole mixture was evaporated to dryness by gradual increase in temperature up to 100°C. Obtained solid was then calcined at 600°C for 6h in air. The catalyst was denoted as 2Pt-CeO2 CD. 2.1.2 Hydrothermal method (1.8Pt-CeO2 HT) In a typical hydrothermal method 5.03g Poly-diallyldimethylammonium chloride (PDADMAC) was dissolved in 100ml distilled water by stirring it for 1h at room temperature (30–35°C). Then 5.04g of cerium nitrate hexahydrate [Ce(NO3)2.6H2O] dissolved in 20ml water was added drop wise to the polymer solution and continued stirring for 1h followed by the addition of Pt salt solution containing 0.08g of tetraamineplatinum(II) nitrate, dissolved in a solution containing 0.08g of CTAB, 10ml of ethanol and 10ml distilled water. The whole mixture solution was then continued stirring at room temperature for 2h and then 0.4ml of NH2NH2.H2O was added and continued stirring for 1 more hour. pH of the solution was maintained to 12 using 5 (M) NaOH solutions (in water). After 1h of stirring, whole mixture was put into a stainless steel autoclave and treated at 180°C for 48h. Obtained precipitate after cooling the autoclave at room temperature was washed with excess water and dried at 100°C for 12h. The dried material was then calcined at 600°C for 6h in air and the prepared catalyst was denoted as 1.8Pt-CeO2 HT. 2.1.3 Co-precipitation method (1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre) In a typical co-precipitation method, both the precursor salt of cerium [5.04g cerium nitrate hexahydrate] and Pt [0.08g tetraamineplatinum(II) nitrate] was dissolved in 100ml distilled water and dissolved well by continuous stirring at room temperature. After 1h of stirring, the salt solution was precipitated completely, using 5 (M) NaOH solutions (in water). The precipitate was then washed with excess water to remove sodium and dried at 100°C. The dried material was then calcined at 600°C for 6h in air and the catalyst was denoted as 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre. 2.1.4 Impregnation method (2Pt-CeO2 Imp) Impregnated catalyst was prepared by adding 0.04g of tetraamineplatinum(II) nitrate [Pt(NH3)4(NO3)2] dissolved in 10ml H2O into 1g of previously prepared CeO2 HT dispersed in 100ml distilled water. After 1h of stirring at room temperature, the whole solution was evaporated to dryness by gradual increase in temperature up to 100°C. The dried solid was then calcined at 600°C for 6h in air and the catalyst was denoted as 2Pt-CeO2 Imp. 2.2 Characterization Surface area analysis of the prepared samples were done at −196°C with a Mircromeritics ASAP (2020) using the BET equation. Degasification of the sample was done at 350°C for 6h before analysis. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns of the samples were recorded on a Proto Analytical X-ray Diffraction System (AXRD) fitted with a Cu Kα radiation source. X-ray diffraction patterns of all the samples were recorded in 10°–80° region with 0.04 step size (Dwell time=1s). Thermal stability of the catalysts, was checked from the XRD pattern of the after reaction catalyst compared with the XRD pattern of fresh catalyst. To check the reducibility of the catalysts, TPR experiments for the samples were carried out in a Micromeritics, Auto Chem II 2920 instrument connected with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). TPR analysis for all the samples were done in the temperature range of 40–1000°C with an increment of 10°Cmin−1, using helium as carrier gas. Metal dispersion analysis was carried out by Micromeritics, Auto Chem II 2920 instrument connected with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and Quadrupole mass analyzer connected online with the TPR instrument. SEM images of the prepared samples were taken on a FEI Quanta 200F, using a tungsten filament doped with lanthanum hexaboride (LaB6) as the X-ray source, fitted with an ETD detector with high vacuum mode, using secondary electrons and an acceleration tension of 10 or 30kV. Analysis of the samples was done by spreading them on a carbon tape. Elemental analysis of the samples was carried out by energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX). Distribution of all elements of the catalyst was also checked by elemental mapping, using same spectrophotometer. TEM images of the prepared samples were collected using a Jeol JEM 2100 microscope. The samples were prepared by mounting an ethanol-dispersed sample on a lacey carbon Formvar coated Cu grid. Thermo Scientific K-Alpha X-ray photoelectron spectrometer was used for X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) of the samples and binding energies (±0.1eV) were determined with the reference peak position of C 1s at 284.6eV. The XPS spectra of the O 1s, C 1s, Pt 4f, Ce 3d regions were measured. Calibration of the binding energy (BE) scale was done by using the C 1s (BE=284.6eV) signal. 2.3 Catalytic experiments POM reaction was carried out in a fixed-bed down flow reactor at atmospheric pressure. Typically, 60mg of catalyst was used for the catalytic experiment. The catalyst mixed with diluent was placed in between two quartz wool plugged in the center of the 32cm long quartz tube reactor (internal diameter=4mm). Before reaction the catalyst was reduced with 20% H2 balanced He gas at 400°C. The reaction was carried out at different temperatures ranging between 350°C and 800°C. Weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) was varied between 5000 and 500000mlg−1 h−1 with a molar ratio of O2: CH4: He=1:2:17. The reaction products were analyzed using an online gas chromatography (Agilent 7890A) fitted with a TCD detector using different columns Molecular sieves (for analyzing H2) and PoraPack-Q (for analyzing CH4, CO2 and CO). The carbon balance and the material balance were calculated to be in between 98% to 102%. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Characterizations 3.1.1 Physicochemical properties To get a good idea about the physicochemical properties of different Pt-CeO2 catalysts prepared by different methods, we carried out the BET-surface area analysis and the obtained results are shown in Table 1 . Hydrothermally prepared CeO2 HT showed a decrease in surface area from 71.5m2/g to 64.7m2/g after depositing 2wt% Pt over it. 1.8Pt-CeO2 HT catalyst prepared by hydrothermal method showed very high surface area compared to the co-precipitated and impregnated catalysts. To get a much better idea about the reasons of the differences in catalysts surface areas, we calculated the catalysts particles sizes from Scherrer equation and TEM analysis. The obtained results showed that the CeO2 particles of 2Pt-CeO2 CD and 1.8Pt-CeO2 HT catalysts are almost of same size but the Pt particles for the 1.8Pt-CeO2 HT catalyst were a bit larger in size. This may be due to the fact that during hydrothermal treatment for 48h, Pt particles formed larger crystals. TEM images of 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre and 2Pt-CeO2 Imp catalyst showed agglomerated particles. 2Pt-CeO2 Imp catalyst showed about 40–70nm particles in agglomerated form, whereas 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre catalyst showed highly agglomerated particles without any definite size or shape. So, from the observations it was clear that agglomeration of catalyst particles was the reason for low surface area of 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre and 2Pt-CeO2 Imp catalysts. 3.1.2 Pt dispersion analysis Catalytic activities depend on active metal dispersion and size of active metals of the catalysts [21,38,52]. As XRD, SEM and TEM analysis did not significantly reveal the nature of Pt-particles, especially the size of it, we carried out Pt dispersion analysis by H2-chemisorption method [21], connecting a mass analyzer to the outlet of the metal dispersion unit to further examine and measure the Pt-particle sizes of different catalysts. The pulse chemisorption analysis was carried out with 10%H2 balance He gas at 35°C. From the obtained results (Table 2 ), it can be seen that the Pt-particle size and its dispersion is highly dependent on catalyst preparation procedures. Controlled deposition process described in this report, showed superior results in terms of Pt dispersion and Pt particle size. In case of 2Pt-CeO2 CD catalyst, high surface area, morphology and size controlling agent (CTAB, NH2NH2.H2O) played the most important role for Pt particle formation and its distribution over the catalyst surface during synthesis [21]. Hydrothermally prepared catalyst (1.8Pt-CeO2 HT) showed much lower Pt-dispersion and higher Pt particle size compared to 2Pt-CeO2 CD catalyst, but showed much higher Pt-dispersion than 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre and 2Pt-CeO2 Imp catalyst. Lower Pt dispersion and a bit larger Pt particle size in case of 1.8Pt-CeO2 HT catalyst was may be due to the crystal growth during 48h hydrothermal treatment at 180°C. Much lower Pt dispersion of 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre catalyst was due to agglomeration of catalyst particles and uncontrolled deposition of Pt over the CeO2 support, whereas in case of 2Pt-CeO2 Imp catalyst, the reason may be uncontrolled crystal formation in absence of any morphology controlling template like CTAB, which caused highly agglomerated catalyst particles with much larger crystals of Pt. 3.1.3 X-ray diffraction analysis (XRD) Crystalinity and the phase of different species formed in the prepared catalysts were examined by X-ray diffraction analysis. All the XRD patterns of prepared catalysts (Fig. 1 Aa–d) showed the formation of cubic CeO2 crystals (JCPDS Card 81-0792). The XRD pattern of 2Pt-CeO2 CD (Fig. 1Aa) showed only the peaks for cubic CeO2 crystals, but no peak for any Pt species was observed [21]. This was due to low Pt loading, high Pt dispersion and below 5nm Pt particles, which were not detected by XRD [12,21,56–58], as it is a bulk sensitive technique and below 5nm particles are not detectable [57,58]. Hydrothermally prepared catalyst (1.8Pt-CeO2 HT) (Fig. 1Ab) and impregnated catalyst (2Pt-CeO2 Imp) (Fig. 1Ac) also did not show any peaks for Pt species. This was may be due to presence of highly dispersed Pt particles or the Pt particles were present as PtxOy (x, y=1, 2, 3 or 4) [59–63]. From metal dispersion analysis it was found that the Pt particles are larger than 5nm for these two catalysts. So, more likely reason for the absence of any peaks for Pt species is that it is present as Pt-oxides. 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre catalyst prepared by conventional co-precipitation method, showed the presence of Pt2O3 species (JCPDS Card 74-1870) (Fig. 1Ad). The XRD peaks at 2θ values 35.3° and 40.9° was due to (211) and (220) planes of Pt3O4 species. Effect of reaction condition was also examined by XRD analysis of spent catalysts (Fig. 1Ba-d). All the catalysts showed presence of metallic Pt except 2Pt-CeO2 CD catalyst (Fig. 1Ba), which did not show any peak for any Pt species (JCPDS Card No.87-0646). Presence of metallic Pt was due to pre-reduction and the reduction of Pt-oxide particles present in the catalyst by the produced hydrogen during catalysis [21]. Absence of peak for any Pt-species was due to the small size of Pt particles (below 5nm) even after catalysis [21]. There is also a possibility of changes in particles size below 5nm range (say changes in particles sizes from 1nm to 4nm or vice versa), which was not detected by XRD technique. Presence of sharp peaks for metallic Pt in case of 1.8Pt-CeO2 HT (Fig. 1Bb), 2Pt-CeO2 Imp (Fig. 1Bc) and 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre (Fig. 1Bd) catalysts was due to sintering of Pt particles during catalysis [21,64]. The observations indicated that thermal stability of 1.8Pt-CeO2 HT, 2Pt-CeO2 Imp and 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre catalysts was low [21,35,65] and the catalysts deactivates with time on stream. 3.1.4 Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) Morphology of the prepared catalysts was characterized by TEM analysis. The analysis showed that 2–5nm Pt particles were deposited on the surface of 40–70nm CeO2 HT support particles of 2Pt-CeO2 CD catalyst (Fig. 2 Aa). From the TEM image of 1.8Pt-CeO2 HT catalyst (Fig. 2Ab) Pt particles were not distinguished separately, whereas 2Pt-CeO2 Imp (Fig. 2Ac) and 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre (Fig. 2Ad) catalyst showed agglomerated catalyst particles. TEM image of 2Pt-CeO2 Imp catalyst showed agglomerated CeO2 HT particles but TEM image of 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre catalyst showed no definite morphology of the particles. During hydrothermal synthesis of 1.8Pt-CeO2 HT catalyst, may be the Pt particles formed larger crystals because of heat treatment at 180°C for 48h. So, the larger crystals of Pt particles were not easily distinguishable by TEM analysis, whereas the uncontrolled synthesis process (impregnation) may have played the role for agglomeration of 2Pt-CeO2 Imp catalyst particles. 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre catalyst was prepared by simple precipitation of the precursor salts without the presence of any size or morphology controlling agent (Templates) and it may be the cause of the indefinite morphology of the catalyst particles. Morphology of spent catalysts for analysis of the effect of reaction condition was also carried out using TEM analysis (Fig. 2Ba–d). TEM image of spent 2Pt-CeO2 CD (Fig. 2Ba) catalyst showed almost unchanged morphology due to high thermal stability of the catalyst [21]. Spent 1.8Pt-CeO2 HT (Fig. 2Bb) catalyst also showed almost unchanged morphology of catalyst particles but XRD of spent 1.8Pt-CeO2 HT catalyst indicated the formation of larger Pt crystals. From the TEM image of 1.8Pt-CeO2 HT catalyst, identification of Pt particles was difficult because similar sized CeO2 crystals were also present. On the contrary, both spent 2Pt-CeO2 Imp (Fig. 2Bc) and spent 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre (Fig. 2Bd) catalysts showed highly irregular and sintered particles. From this observation, it can be concluded that the catalyst prepared by controlled deposition method showed high thermal stability compared to the catalyst prepared by other conventional methods [66]. 3.1.5 H2-Temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) Cerium oxide shows two reduction peaks in its TPR profile, one at about 500°C due to reduction of surface oxygen and other one at above 700°C due to bulk reduction of cerium oxide [21,67]. Surface oxygen or OSC of cerium oxide plays an important role in catalyzing methane by partial oxidation to produce syngas [19,41,47,68]. Agglomeration of CeO2 particles and larger size of CeO2 particles reduce the surface oxygen [40,46]. Again, addition of Pt to cerium oxide can change the reducibility of catalyst particles. On the other hand, cerium oxide helps to form smaller Pt particles by higher Pt dispersion, which is beneficial to catalysts activity [21,28,36,40,47,69]. Reducibility of the prepared catalysts was analyzed by H2-TPR analysis and it was observed that the reducibility of catalyst particles was dependent on the size of particles and the synthesis procedure [14,21,64]. Different sized PtOx and CeO2 particles of different catalysts caused different metal support interactions and caused the changes in reducibility of catalysts. Fig. 3 a–d shows the reducibility of prepared catalysts. H2-TPR pattern of 2Pt-CeO2 CD catalyst (Fig. 3a) showed most easily reducible PtOx particles due to formation of very small sized PtOx particles compared to the other catalysts [21,70]. Deconvolution of the PtOx reduction peak of 2Pt-CeO2 CD catalyst showed two peaks at 159°C and 213°C. The peak for PtOx reduction of 2Pt-CeO2 CD catalyst showed the presence of multiple peaks due to formation of different sized Pt particles, which created different metal support interaction with support CeO2 particles [21]. The catalyst prepared by hydrothermal method (1.8Pt-CeO2 HT) (Fig. 3b) showed two PtOx reduction peaks after deconvolution, a sharp peak at 251°C and a peak at 230–330°C. The sharp peak may be due to uniformity (similar size) of Pt particles formed during synthesis, which are all reducible at that particular temperature. Pt particles size of 1.8Pt-CeO2 HT catalyst was uniform but was larger than Pt particles of 2Pt-CeO2 CD catalyst as it can be seen from the reducibility of Pt particles. The observation was also evident from Pt-dispersion analysis. H2-TPR patterns 2Pt-CeO2 Imp (Fig. 3c) and 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre (Fig. 3d) catalysts showed one single broad peak for Pt reduction due to reduction of larger Pt crystals, which takes much more time and higher temperature to reduce by the diffusion of hydrogen over PtOx particles during H2-TPR analysis. Scheme 1 represents a model schematic representation of reduction or activation of different sized PtOx particles during H2-TPR analysis or during catalysis (by the reducing agents). From it, we can see that at particular temperature smaller particles with fewer PtOx species gets easily and completely reduced, whereas larger particles with higher number of PtOx species were incompletely reduced. Larger particles needed higher temperature as core species are not readily exposed to the reduction during the diffusion of hydrogen over the particle surface. So, the activation of larger particles requires higher temperatures and smaller particles can be easily reduced or activated. Higher dispersion led to the formation of higher surface oxygen vacancies, which promoted the reduction of PtOx particles for 2Pt-CeO2 CD and 1.8Pt-CeO2 HT catalysts [56,71]. Higher the Pt-dispersion, higher is the presence of surface Pt species and lower is the bulk Pt-species and vice-versa. It is also reported that surface particles are more easily reducible than the bulk structure due to accessibility for reduction [72]. Formation of larger particles and bulk aggregates led to the higher reduction temperature of Pt-species in 2Pt-CeO2 Imp and 2Pt-CeO2 CoPre catalysts [73]. 3.1.6 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) Surface analysis of prepared catalysts was carried out by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and the obtained spectra for different catalysts are represented in Fig. 4 Aa–d. All the catalysts showed presence of Pt-oxide species. Pt4f7/2 and Pt4f5/2 XPS peaks at 73.8eV and 77.2eV of fresh 2Pt-CeO2 CD catalyst (Fig. 4Aa) confirmed the presence of PtO in the catalyst surface. The catalyst prepared by hydrothermal method (1.8Pt-CeO2 HT) (Fig. 4Ab) showed a bit complicated spectra. Pt4f7/2 and Pt4f5/2 peaks at binding energy values 73.7eV and 77.1eV indicated the presence of PtO, whereas Pt 4f7/2 and Pt4f5/2 peaks at binding energy values 75.8eV and 79.1eV could be due to Pt3O4. The XPS peak of 2Pt-CeO2 Imp catalyst (Fig. 4Ac) showed peaks of Pt4f7/2 and Pt4f5/2 at 73.6eV and 77.1eV, which was due to PtO species. Co-precipitated catalyst also (1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre) (Fig. 4Ad) showed presence of both PtO and Pt3O4 by the presence of Pt4f7/2 and Pt4f5/2 XPS peaks at binding energy values 73.2eV and 76.6eV, 76.0eV and 79.4eV respectively. Presence of Pt3O4 in 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre catalyst was also confirmed by the XRD analysis. Fig. 4B shows XPS patterns of reduced activated catalysts before reaction. The observed patterns of all the catalysts showed that all the surface PtOx-particles were reduced to its metallic form, which is the active species for POM reaction. 2Pt-CeO2 CD, 1.8Pt-CeO2 HT, 2Pt-CeO2 Imp and 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre catalysts showed Pt4f7/2 XPS peak at 71.0eV, 70.9eV, 71.1eV, 71.0eV and satellite Pt4f5/2 XPS peaks at 74.2eV, 74.1eV, 74.5eV, 74.3eV, which is the characteristic metallic Pt peaks. So, in the reduced catalysts all the surface Pt-species were in metallic form. XPS analysis of spent catalysts was also carried out and represented in Fig. 4C. All the catalyst showed metallic Pt on the surface due to the reduction of Pt-oxides by the produced hydrogen during catalysis. Spent 2Pt-CeO2 CD catalyst (Fig. 4Ca) showed only the presence of metallic Pt [21]. Pt4f7/2 and Pt4f5/2 peaks at binding energy values 70.9eV and 74.2eV is corresponding to the metallic Pt species. All the other spent catalysts also showed the presence of Pt-oxides and hydroxide species. XPS peaks of Pt 4f7/2 at binding energy values 70.9eV, 72.3eV, 73.6eV, 75.0eV and Pt4f5/2 peaks at values 74.2eV, 75.6eV, 76.9eV, 78.3eV of 1.8Pt-CeO2 HT catalyst (Fig. 4Cb) are due to metallic Pt, Pt(OH)2, PtO and PtO2 respectively [21]. The XPS peak of Pt 4f7/2 of 2Pt-CeO2 Imp catalyst (Fig. 4Cc) at 71.0eV, 72.5eV and 73.7eV binding energy values are due to Pt, Pt(OH)2 and PtO respectively and Pt 4f7/2 of 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre catalyst (Fig. 4Cd) at binding energy values 71.0eV, 72.4eV and 73.1eV, 74.9eV are corresponding to Pt, Pt(OH)2, PtO and PtO2 respectively. Presence of Pt-oxide species and hydroxide species was due to re-oxidation of reduced Pt species and the hydroxide species was formed by the reaction with water produced over the 1.8Pt-CeO2 HT, 2Pt-CeO2 Imp and 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre catalysts during catalysis [21]. Re-oxidation took place by the oxygen, present as feed and the water were produced by the complete oxidation of methane and consumption of the produced hydrogen by the oxygen. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) is a surface analysis technique. So, the amount of Pt-species present on the surface of the catalyst will reflect in the XPS spectra. The species present in the bulk could not be detected and it reflects in intensity of peaks. Low intense XPS peaks are also an indication of the surface active particles moving into the bulk. 3.1.7 Methane activation Theoretically, with higher Pt-dispersion and smaller Pt-particles size, 2Pt-CeO2 CD catalyst should have larger Pt-surface area and the order in respect to decreasing Pt-surface area of the catalysts should be 2Pt-CeO2 CD >1.8Pt-CeO2 HT >2Pt-CeO2 Imp >1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre. All the catalysts were reduced at 400°C with 20%H2 balanced Helium gas. The purpose of reduction was to reduce different Pt-species present in different catalysts as metallic Pt is the active species of POM. From TPR analysis, it can be seen that Pt-species in all the catalysts are reducible below 400°C and the reducibility of Pt-particles decreased with increasing size. Pt-particles with larger size reduced at higher temperatures due to inhibition of reduction of these particles caused by agglomeration (2Pt-CeO2 Imp, 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre catalysts). From TEM images of the spent 2Pt-CeO2 Imp spent 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre catalysts, it can be seen that the catalysts particles are sintered, which reduced the exposer of Pt-particles during reaction and affected the re-activation process of these particles. Several literature reports suggested that catalyst with higher metal dispersion and smaller particles are more easily reducible and easy to activate [21,56,70–74]. Methane, a non-polar molecule with very high CH bond energy (104kcalmol−1) [75–77] is very inactive and it is quite a tough task to activate methane at lower temperatures. A suitable composition of active and support material leads to the formation of smaller active particles with beneficial effects like strong metal-support interaction and higher number of active particles, which are reported to be capable of activating methane at lower temperatures [21,70]. Tellinger et al. reported that Pt nanoparticles supported on a reducible support like CeO2 is much more active at lower temperatures than a combination of Pt and Al2O3 [37]. Now, catalytic activity of a catalyst varies not only with support material but also with preparation method of the catalyst and the size of catalyst particles including both the size of active particles and support particles [21,52,64,70]. Here, we have prepared Pt-CeO2 catalysts by four different methods and tested its catalytic activities for POM. Cerium oxide is reported to be a powerful promoter, which modifies structural and electronic properties of catalysts and enhance the noble metal reducibility and reduces coking during methane reforming reactions [19,24,28,38,40,47,68]. It was observed that catalytic activities of prepared catalysts were dependent on the catalyst preparation procedures and catalyst particles sizes. 2Pt-CeO2 CD, 1.8Pt-CeO2 HT, 2Pt-CeO2 Imp and 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre catalyst activated methane at 400°C, 500°C, 600°C and 600°C. We carried out the activation energy calculations using Arrhenius equation and found that catalyst prepared by controlled deposition of Pt over CeO2 HT nanocrystals had lowest activation energy compared to the other catalysts prepared by different conventional methods. Arrhenius plots for different catalysts are shown in Fig. 5 a–d. The analysis was carried out below 10% methane conversions over different catalysts. TEM analysis revealed that 2Pt-CeO2 CD catalyst has smaller Pt particles (average 3.2nm) and smaller CeO2 nanocrystals (average 44nm), which created better metal-support interaction due to high Pt dispersion (58.9%) and higher number of active particles on the catalyst surface. Methane activation energy for 2Pt-CeO2 CD catalyst was lowest among the catalyst prepared by different conventional methods. Although, 1.8Pt-CeO2 HT catalyst had smaller CeO2 crystals (average 40nm), but comparatively larger Pt particles (8.6nm, from TEM) formed due to crystal growth of Pt particles during hydrothermal treatment of the catalyst at 180°C for 48h. Larger Pt particles lowered Pt dispersion and also lowered the active metallic (Pt) surface area available for catalysis. As a result of this, catalytic activity of hydrothermally prepared catalyst (1.8Pt-CeO2 HT) decreased and methane activation energy increased compared to the 2Pt-CeO2 CD catalyst. 2Pt-CeO2 Imp and 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre catalysts activated methane at much higher temperature due to much higher activation energy over these two catalysts. Higher methane activation energy over 2Pt-CeO2 Imp and 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre catalysts was due to much larger Pt particles formed during uncontrolled impregnation and uncontrolled precipitation respectively. Calculated methane activation energy over 2Pt-CeO2 CD, 1.8Pt-CeO2 HT, 2Pt-CeO2 Imp and 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre catalysts was 73.48kJmol−1, 84.28kJmol−1, 96.38kJmol−1 and 99.25kJmol−1. Here, the surface oxygen of CeO2 plays very important role for methane activation also. Surface oxygen depends on catalyst surface area, which is again dependent on the support CeO2 particle size. H2-TPR analysis (peak at about 500°C) indicated that 1.8Pt-CeO2 HT catalyst had higher surface oxygen (or OSC). Agglomerated catalyst particles of 2Pt-CeO2 Imp and 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre catalysts reduced OSC of the catalyst, which was also evident from H2-TPR analysis. Low temperature light off of the catalyst occurred for 2Pt-CeO2 CD and 1.8Pt-CeO2 HT catalyst because CeO2 modified the catalysts by more lattice vacancies and increased oxygen mobility [38,40,78]. In all the cases, irrespective of the catalyst, all oxygen molecules were consumed when methane started reacting. But it can be seen that the catalyst with smaller particles activated oxygen molecules at lower temperatures. In general, methane activation by oxygen occurs via successive formation of active oxygen (O*) and hydrogen containing carbon species (CHx*) [79]. CeO2 plays an important role for oxygen activation during reaction with methane and enhances catalyst activity [79,80]. Nonstoichiometric structure of cerium oxide expressed as CeO2-x, with high oxygen release and storage property or redox property, enhances reversible activation of oxygen in CeO2-x lattice and this oxygen activate methane [79,80]. H2-TPR patterns of 2Pt-CeO2 CD and 1.8Pt-CeO2 HT showed that substantial amount of easily reducible oxygen species present in cerium oxides (peak at about 500°C) but other two catalysts (2Pt-CeO2 Imp and 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre) lack the property. These easily reducible oxygen species enhances activation of methane [79]. Again the increase in metal dispersion increased metal-support interfacial sites, where methane activation takes place. At Pt-CeO2 interfacial sites, the oxygen species is loosely bound to the support surface and are easy to reduce [64], which also improved the activity of the catalysts with higher Pt-dispersions. Active metallic Pt sites are responsible for the activation methane and the unsaturated CeO2-x is responsible to activate oxygen molecules. 3.1.8 Catalytic performance Methane conversion was checked by varying the pellet size and WHSV of the reaction. The observations led us to rule out the transport limitations, as the change in conversion was negligible [21]. Catalytic activities of different catalysts prepared by different methods were carried out at temperature range 350–800°C and the results are shown in Fig. 6 . Very recently we have reported the synthesis and activity of Pt-CeO2 catalyst for POM [21]. In this report we have shown that controlled deposition of Pt particles over hydrothermally prepared CeO2 created better metal support interaction as compared to the Pt deposited over CeO2 surface by conventional impregnation method. The reported catalyst was prepared following almost the same procedure as it is described here in preparation of 2Pt-CeO2 CD catalyst. From the previous report and the present study, we can say that 25% NH3 played better role for CeO2 crystal formation with higher surface area as compared to 5(M) NaOH. Comparatively low pH (∼8) maintenance during the CeO2 preparation resulted in higher surface area of the support CeO2 [21] as compared to the CeO2 prepared at higher pH (∼12) (current study). Comparatively high surface area of the reported support created better Pt-dispersion (64.7%) than the support reported in this study (58.9% for 2Pt-CeO2 CD catalyst) and the catalytic activity of the reported catalyst was better than the catalyst reported here. From Fig. 6a, it can be seen that catalytic activity of 2Pt-CeO2 CD and 1.8Pt-CeO2 HT catalysts was quite high compared to the other two catalysts, 2Pt-CeO2 Imp and 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre. From Pt dispersion and TEM analysis, it was confirmed that Pt dispersion was very high for 2Pt-CeO2 CD catalyst and moderate for 1.8Pt-CeO2 HT catalyst, whereas comparatively very low for 2Pt-CeO2 Imp and 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre catalysts. So, number of active particles also followed the same order 2Pt-CeO2 CD >1.8Pt-CeO2 HT >2Pt-CeO2 Imp >1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre, whereas size of Pt particles followed exactly the reverse order. Ignition temperature for POM over 2Pt-CeO2 CD, 1.8Pt-CeO2 HT, 2Pt-CeO2 Imp and 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre catalyst was 400°C, 500°C, 600°C and 600°C respectively. Therefore, it is the size and number of Pt particles played the role for low temperature light off for POM. Depending on the catalyst preparation methods, catalysts morphology, surface area, Pt dispersion and particle size was found to be varied and it directly effected on catalysts activity. Controlled deposition of Pt particles on the support (CeO2 HT), in presence of morphology and size controlling agents led to the formation of smaller Pt particles, which effectively created better metal-support interactions between Pt and CeO2 HT nanoparticles [21,66]. On the other hand, hydrothermal synthesis formed little bit larger Pt particles by crystal growth of PtOx particles, whereas uncontrolled deposition of PtOx particles and agglomeration of support (CeO2 HT) particles during impregnation process caused the formation of much bigger PtOx particles and very low metal support interactions between the active Pt particles and agglomerated support particles. Co-precipitated catalyst (1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre) showed formation of highly agglomerated catalyst particles and Pt particles size obtained from Pt-dispersion analysis was very high due to uncontrolled precipitation of the precursor salts, with too low Pt-dispersion, which affected catalytic activity of the catalyst. So, from the observation of catalytic properties and their catalytic activity, it can be said that smaller Pt particles formed during controlled deposition of Pt particles were most active during POM compared to the catalysts prepared by other conventional methods. The reactions of methane with oxygen is complete oxidation and partial oxidation CH4 +O2 →CO2 +2H2O Highly exothermic CH4 +0.5O2 →CO+2H2 Mild exothermic At lower temperature complete oxidation is favored over POM. Production of synthesis gas can take place via direct route or indirect route; both the routes are reported to be possible and it varies with catalytic property of catalyst [38,40,81–83]. Selectivity of the products depends on active particle sizes as reported by Kondratenko et al. [52]. It is also reported that H2 and CO (Syngas) selectivity in POM increases with decreasing active particle size i.e. for smaller active particles (here it is Pt), selectivity towards POM products are comparatively higher at a particular temperature. Larger active particle leads to total oxidation products [52]. Obtained results in our case were also similar. The route for formation of POM products depends on nature of active species, temperature, WHSV and even on the catalyst calcination temperatures [84–87]. It is also reported that even over same catalyst, POM mechanism switches from direct to indirect or indirect to direct mechanism [84,87]. Over some catalyst, formation of partial oxidation products also proceeds via both direct and indirect routes [88,89]. So, distinction between these two routes is difficult. From Fig. 6b, it can be seen that rate of CO formation, which is also an indication of selectivity of POM products (CO and H2) follows the order: 2Pt-CeO2 CD >1.8Pt-CeO2 HT >2Pt-CeO2 Imp >1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre. The observations revealed that catalysts with smaller Pt-particles show superior activity for POM reaction, whereas over larger Pt-particles complete oxidation of methane was favored. In all the cases, rate of CO formation was increased with temperature irrespective of CeO2 and Pt-particles sizes. Selectivity’s of partial oxidation products CO and H2 was found to be dependent on catalyst preparation methods and catalyst particles sizes (Fig. 7 a–d). Irrespective of the catalyst preparation methods, selectivity of CO and H2/CO ratio increased with increasing temperature and methane conversion over all the catalysts. Among the prepared catalysts, 2Pt-CeO2 CD catalyst (Fig. 7a) showed superior CO and H2 selectivities due to smaller Pt particles and high metal dispersion with superior metal-support interaction, which kept the size of Pt particles unchanged during catalysis [21,35,66]. Lower CO selectivity at lower temperatures was due to the fact that complete oxidation of methane was favored over POM because of highly exothermic nature of complete oxidation of methane reaction as compared to POM [38]. The same observations were noted for all other catalysts also. With increasing temperature, H2/CO ratio was found to be increased and reached 1.99 at 800°C, over 2Pt-CeO2 CD catalyst. Lower H2/CO ratio at lower temperatures was due to consumptions of produced hydrogen by the oxygen present as reaction feed. With increasing Pt particle size, which was the result of different preparation methods, generation of partial oxidation products was observed at higher temperatures indicating that the smaller Pt particles were more selective towards partial oxidation [21,52]. The catalyst prepared by hydrothermal method (1.8Pt-CeO2 HT) (Fig. 7b) showed formation of partial oxidation products at 550°C and the other two catalysts 2Pt-CeO2 Imp (Fig. 7c) and 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre (Fig. 7d) showed formation of CO and H2 at 700°C, whereas over 2Pt-CeO2 CD catalyst, formation of CO and H2 was observed at 400°C. From the selectivity plots it is evident that even at 800°C, there was enough complete oxidation products CO2 and H2O was present, which can deactivate catalysts by re-oxidation or hydroxide formation of the Pt-species over 1.8Pt-CeO2 HT, 2Pt-CeO2 Imp and 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre catalysts. Observed results indicated that smaller Pt particles generated by controlled deposition of Pt was catalytically superior and catalytic activity and selectivity of the desired product was dependent on catalyst preparation procedures. Particles size obtained from TEM analysis and chemisorption analysis showed quite a difference. TEM analysis could not detect very fine particles present in the catalyst but during chemisorption analysis, very fine Pt-particles also contributed and this is why the particles size calculation from metal dispersion analysis showed lower value of Pt-particles size. We have calculated TOF values (based on surface Pt-particles obtained from H2-chemisorption) with respect to temperature over 2Pt-CeO2 CD catalyst and with respect to Pt-dispersions for different catalysts. The results are shown in Table 3 , which shows that with increasing temperature TOF values over 2Pt-CeO2 CD catalyst increased continuously [90,91], which was also the case for other catalysts. From Table 3, it can be seen that with decreasing Pt-dispersion, TOF values was also increased. Earlier reports also revealed same observations [28,92–94]. If support does not take part in C-H bond activation then only the active metal particles are responsible for C-H bond activation [95]. As the metal dispersion increased, the number of active sites on catalyst surface increased and the TOF also followed the same. Support plays a very important role in POM reaction [92,93] and our observation also revealed that although the Pt-particles sizes were bigger for 2Pt-CeO2 Imp and 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre catalysts, the catalyst was still very much active and activated higher number of C-H bonds in the same time interval compared to the catalysts with smaller Pt-particles and higher Pt-dispersion [92], which may be due to the influence of CeO2 support. So, metal dispersion is not playing the major role here [92,93]. Higher TOF values were due to normalizing the rate with lower metal dispersion values [94]. TOF=number of CH4 molecules converted per single active site per unit time 3.1.9 Effect of WHSV (weight hourly space velocity) or contact time Fig. 8 depicts methane conversion variation with WHSV or contact time. With increasing WHSV, contact time of the reactant molecules with the catalyst surface decreased, which led to decreasing amount of reactant adsorption on the catalyst surface [21,96]. Low amount of adsorbed reactant molecules consequently led to low methane conversions with decreasing contact time. Over all the catalyst, decreasing trend of methane conversions was observed with increasing WHSV but higher number of active sites with higher active metallic surface area of 2Pt-CeO2 CD and 1.8Pt-CeO2 HT was main reason for comparatively higher methane conversions as compared to 2Pt-CeO2 Imp and 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre catalysts. 3.1.10 Stability Deactivation of POM catalysts mainly occurs due to coking or re-oxidation of active particles. The catalysts resistant to coking are more likely to be deactivated by the re-oxidation of the active species. Pt is reported to be highly coke resisting and the support (CeO2) is also known to have excellent coke removal property [21,59,60,78,93]. So, Pt-CeO2 catalysts are more likely to be deactivated by re-oxidation of the reduced Pt particles by the oxidants present in feed or reaction products. Stability of the catalysts was tested by time on stream (TOS) study at 800°C and the observations are shown in Fig. 9 . For 24h, there was no decrease in catalytic activity over 2Pt-CeO2 CD catalyst observed indicating that the catalyst particle size was unchanged [52]. 2Pt-CeO2 CD catalyst was more selective towards POM products CO and H2, both are reducing agents. Smaller Pt particles with better metal-support interaction between Pt and CeO2 nanoparticles hindered the sintering of catalyst particles [21,52] and maintained selectivity of POM products almost constant throughout the TOS reaction at 800°C. So, there was minimum possibility of re-oxidation of reduced Pt particles. TEM image of spent 2Pt-CeO2 CD catalyst showed no sign of sintering of catalyst particles and the XPS analysis also showed only the presence of metallic Pt on the surface of 2Pt-CeO2 CD catalyst. Constant activity of the 2Pt-CeO2 CD catalyst indicated minimal or no changes in particles sizes [52]. 1.8Pt-CeO2 HT catalyst showed continuous decrease in activity during TOS reaction. The characterization techniques revealed that Pt particles were larger in spent 1.8Pt-CeO2 HT catalyst as compared to the size of Pt particles present in the fresh 1.8Pt-CeO2 HT catalyst. So, there was some sintering of Pt particles took place during catalysis at 800°C. This could be due to lower metal support interaction between Pt particles and support CeO2 particles. XPS analysis showed that spent 1.8Pt-CeO2 HT catalyst contains three types of Pt species, metallic Pt, PtO and Pt(OH)2. From the selectivity analysis it was evident that even at 800°C, there was above 15% complete oxidation products were present during catalysis over 1.8Pt-CeO2 HT catalyst. Pesence of PtO in spent 1.8Pt-CeO2 HT catalyst may be due to re-oxidation of the reduced Pt particles by oxygen present in the feed or the oxygen generated by the decomposition of CO2 to CO and O. Presence of Pt(OH)2 could be due to hydroxide formation of Pt by H2O produced during TOS reaction [21]. In case of 2Pt-CeO2 Imp and 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre catalysts same results were observed. POM to CO and H2 is overall a reducible environment but the environment depends on catalyst property, reactant conversion and selectivity of the products as CO2 and H2O can also be the products during POM by complete oxidation of methane. First of all, if consumption of O2 and selectivity of CO and H2 is very high, then the environment becomes highly reducible. But as consumption of O2 by methane decreases, there will be excess O2 molecules, which can oxidize the active metallic particles. Secondly, if selectivity of CO2 and H2O becomes very high, it creates an oxidizing environment. In case of larger active particles this kind of environment is very much possible. Again, if oxygen storage capacity of the catalyst is high or high amount of oxygen is present within its crystal (as CeO2 supported catalysts) then the environment becomes further more oxidizing. From Figs. 7 and 9, it can be seen that oxygen consumption due to methane conversion over 1.8Pt-CeO2 HT, 2Pt-CeO2 Imp and 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre catalysts are low and further decreased with time. Selectivity of CO2 and H2O is also quite high over these catalysts. So, with increasing time, overall environment in these cases becomes oxidizing and the oxidants like excess oxygen and produced CO2 and H2O can oxidize active metallic Pt particles. TEM analysis of spent 2Pt-CeO2 Imp and spent 1.9Pt-CeO2 CoPre catalyst also revealed one more reason for the catalyst deactivation and it was further sintering of catalysts particles, which reduced the much needed surface area of catalyst and reduced the catalytic activity. Therefore, from the TOS observation it can be said that the catalyst preparation processes has a very crucial role for catalysts activity and stability for POM, as it controls the size of catalyst particles. 4 Conclusions Pt-CeO2 catalysts were prepared by controlled deposition, hydrothermal, impregnation and co-precipitation methods and its catalytic activity and stability was tested for partial oxidation of methane, which revealed that controlled deposition of Pt over hydrothermally prepared CeO2 created better metal-support interaction by the formation of smaller Pt particles and it highly enhanced catalytic activity and stability of the catalyst compared to the catalysts prepared by conventional hydrothermal, impregnation and co-precipitation methods. Controlled deposition of Pt particles in presence of morphology controlling agent (cetyltrimethylammonium bromide) and capping agent (hydrazine) played the crucial role for Pt-species formation with smaller size. Hydrothermal treatment for longer time led to the formation of larger Pt-species for hydrothermally prepared catalyst. Uncontrolled deposition of Pt in absence of any morphology controlling agent and capping agent during impregnation and uncontrolled precipitation during co-precipitation method formed larger catalyst particles and lowered the Pt-dispersion, surface area and consequently decreased the catalytic activity of impregnated and co-precipitated catalysts. The size of active and support particles played major role for the product selectivity and stability of the catalysts. Smaller active particles were more selective towards POM products CO and H2. Larger active particles were more active for complete oxidation. Products like CO2, H2O and the excess oxygen remained after consumption by methane re-oxidized the active metallic Pt-particles. Strong metal-support interaction prevented metal-sintering and it was the main reason for high stability of the catalyst prepared by controlled deposition method. Sintering and re-oxidation of larger Pt species due to low metal support interactions was the major reasons for deactivation of the catalysts prepared by hydrothermal, impregnation and co-precipitation methods. coredata.dc:description: The objective of this study is to explore the effect of catalyst synthesis procedure on the activity of catalysts for partial oxidation of methane. In this aspect, Pt-nanoparticles supported CeO2 catalysts were prepared by Hydrothermal, co-precipitation, impregnation and by controlled deposition of platinum nanoparticles on hydrothermally prepared cerium oxide. Prepared catalysts were characterized by BET-surface area, X-ray diffraction, H2-Chemisorption, Transmission electron microscopy, Temperature programmed reduction, Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. The study revealed that the catalyst preparation procedure plays a very crucial role on morphology, catalyst particle size, metal support interaction and activity of the catalysts. Catalytic activities were tested for partial oxidation of methane in the temperature range 350–800°C. The study revealed that the catalyst prepared by controlled deposition of Pt-nanoparticles on hydrothermally prepared cerium oxide showed better activity for partial oxidation of methane compared to the catalysts prepared by other conventional methods. Controlled deposition of Pt-nanoparticles generated better metal-support interaction compared to the catalysts prepared by conventional hydrothermal, co-precipitation and impregnation methods. All the catalysts showed excellent coke resisting ability but the deactivation of most of the catalyst was found to be caused by catalyst particles sintering and re-oxidation of the Pt particles during catalysis.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis effects on activity and stability of Pt-CeO2 catalysts for partial oxidation of methane
